faq.title: Frequently Asked
faq.description: Resolve key concepts simply and learn how we work.
faq.answer1: Web 2 is the traditional web with centralized platforms. Web 3 adds ownership and verification on blockchain, allowing data and assets to be yours.
faq.question2: What is a wallet and what is an address?
faq.answer2: The wallet is your crypto wallet. Its address is like your account number: it serves to receive or identify assets/actions on the chain.
faq.question3: Do I need to create my own wallet to use the system?
faq.answer3: No. Our flow registers you and internally associates the wallet; you can use the system without installing anything. If you want later, you connect your personal wallet.
faq.moreInfo: More concepts and step-by-step guides on the FAQs page.

faqPage.title: Frequently Asked
faqPage.description: Key concepts explained simply: Web 2 / Web 3, wallets, addresses and TXID.
faqPage.a1: It's the current web dominated by centralized platforms (apps, social networks, company servers) where you trust an intermediary.
faqPage.a2: An evolution that adds blockchain to verify and record actions/assets without relying on a third party. It provides ownership, traceability and public proof.
faqPage.q3: Why do we still use Web 2 if Web 3 exists?
faqPage.a3: Because there are cases where centralized is simpler or faster to use, and in others the public verification of Web 3 is key. We combine both as appropriate.
faqPage.a4: Your crypto wallet. It manages keys and signatures to prove that an action belongs to you. Think of it as your identity/keychain on the blockchain.
faqPage.a5: It's like your account number. It's used to receive or locate your operations on the network. It doesn't reveal your private keys.
faqPage.q6: Do I need to create my wallet to use the system?
faqPage.a6: No. You register normally and we internally associate a wallet. You can use basic functions without installing anything. Then, if you want, you connect your personal wallet.
faqPage.q7: Why do we use the Stacks blockchain?
faqPage.a7: Because it's economical, stable and integrates with Bitcoin. It allows us to anchor data reliably for certificates and public verification.
faqPage.a8: It's the unique identifier of an operation on the blockchain. With it you can check status, block and details to confirm authenticity.
faqPage.a9: Yes. Anyone can check the TXID in a block explorer and confirm that the certificate exists and was issued correctly.
faqPage.q10: What happens if the contract doesn't match the expected one?
faqPage.a10: It indicates that the transaction does not belong to the certificate contract, avoiding false positives.
faqPage.a11: So that verification doesn't depend only on us: the evidence lives on the chain. Still, we offer a simple Web 2 style UX.

dashboard.title: Admin Dashboard
dashboard.dialogChangeManagerDesc: Enter the address of the new manager contract that will be active in the system.
dashboard.dialogChangeSuperAdminDesc: Enter the new super administrator address. This is a critical operation.
dashboard.warningManager1: Only change this if you're deploying a new manager version
dashboard.warningManager2: The manager controls all certificate business logic
dashboard.warningManager3: Make sure the contract is deployed and tested
dashboard.warningSuperAdmin1: This address will have full control of the registry
dashboard.warningSuperAdmin2: Will be able to change the active manager
dashboard.warningSuperAdmin3: You CANNOT recover access if you lose control
dashboard.infoNoteManager: The registry always points to the active manager. Academies interact with the current manager.
dashboard.infoNoteSuperAdmin: The registry super admin is the only account that can modify the central configuration.

dataContract.title: Data Contract Management
dataContract.description: Manage authorized contracts to write data

dataSettings.title: Super Admin Configuration (Data)
dataSettings.description: Manage the super administrator of the certificate-data contract
dataSettings.importantInfo: ‚ö†Ô∏è About the Data Contract Super Admin:
dataSettings.info2: Can change their own address to another account
dataSettings.info3: This is the lowest security level (data layer)
dataSettings.info4: Works in conjunction with the Registry and Manager
dataSettings.dialogChangeSuperAdminDesc: Transfer control of the certificate-data contract to another address
dataSettings.warning1: You will lose access to the certificate-data contract
dataSettings.warning2: Only the new address will be able to authorize/revoke writers
dataSettings.warning3: You CANNOT recover access without the new account
dataSettings.warning4: Make sure you have full control of the new address
dataSettings.infoNoteText: The certificate-data super admin is independent of the registry. It controls who can write data, but not the business logic.
dataSettings.differentAddress: The new address must be different from the current one
dataSettings.transactionSent: Transaction sent. The super admin will be updated upon confirmation.
